title: Why did the Assyrian Empire become Christian? - Quora

response.answer_text: In reality we see that monotheism already existed in the Ancient East, and the Assyrian Nation did not disappear, it was dominated by other invaders and their influence in the region persisted and we see that their language persisted till our days. Today the Assyrian Nation is formed of Christian communities such as the Assyrian Orthodox Church of the East, The Syriac Orthodox Church of Antioch that in the beginning of the twentieth century yet used the Assyrian identification, but due to the religious persecutions they used first the Syrian and afterwards Syriac. There are part of the group the Chaldean Church, the Syrian Catholic and some Protestant groups. Since de Christian Genocide know as SAYFO (1913 - 1926) during the Ottoman Empire and the initial part of the Turkish Republic occurred massive Assyrian immigration to the new Arab States such as Palestine, Syria, Lebanon, Iraq and even into Persia and outside the Middle East, to the Americas; afterwards the Turkish Pogrom during the fifties a great migration occurred to Europe, mainly, Sweden, Switzerland, Austria, Germany, Belgium. Soon after the Iran-Iraq war a great number os Assyrians moved to Australia.

The Assyrian Empire was pretty much dead even before Jesus was born. The last Assyrian empire, the Neo-Assyrian Empire, fell in 609 BC. That’s 600 years prior to what scholars believed to be the birth year of Jesus (generally between 6–4 BC). Afterwards, what was known as Assyria became part of the Neo-Babylonian, Achaemenid Persian, Alexander’s Hellenic, the Seleucid, the Parthian, the Roman, the Sassanian, and the Arab Islamic empires. Its people still remain, however, and they are predominantly Christians today.
